dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the podcast. Today, um, we're diving into something pretty wild: Forbes' list of America's Worst Large Employers for 2021. And, uh, some of the findings are just... shocking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the podcast. Today, um, we're diving into something pretty wild: Forbes' list of America's Worst Large Employers for twenty twenty one. And, uh, some of the findings are just... shocking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These actions, among other initiatives, helped UAB secure the top spot on Forbes list of Americas Best Large Employers 2021.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I'm ready. I mean, we've heard whispers, but tell me, who's topping this, uh, dubious list? What kind of companies are we talking about?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I'm ready. I mean, we've heard whispers, but tell me, who's topping this, uh, dubious list? What kind of companies are we talking about?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, one that really stands out, like, plummeted to the bottom spot, is the University of Alabama at Birmingham. UAB. And when you hear why, it's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, one that really stands out, like, plummeted to the bottom spot, is the University of Alabama at Birmingham. U A B. And when you hear why, it's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These actions, among other initiatives, helped UAB secure the top spot on Forbes list of Americas Best Large Employers 2021.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: UAB? A hospital and university? Wow. What on earth did they do to earn that kind of, um, notoriety?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: U A B? A hospital and university? Wow. What on earth did they do to earn that kind of, um, notoriety?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, during COVID, they had up to 300 patients at a time, 30% in ICU. But here's the kicker: their own president, Dr. Ray Watts, says these patients were *actively sabotaging their care* with complaints. And, like, employees showed "remarkable resentment" because of the stress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, during C O V I D, they had up to three hundred patients at a time, thirty percent in I C U. But here's the kicker: their own president, Doctor Ray Watts, says these patients were actively sabotaging their care with complaints. And, like, employees showed remarkable resentment because of the stress.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Weve had almost up to 300 Covid patients at a time with 30% in an ICU, says President Dr. Ray Watts. They have done it without complaint. The resilience of our employees during these times of greater stress had been remarkable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, patients *sabotaging* their own care? That's a wild accusation. But then, on top of that, the hospital denied its employees personal protective gear to save costs. Like, PPE! During a pandemic!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, patients sabotaging their own care? That's a wild accusation. But then, on top of that, the hospital denied its employees personal protective gear to save costs. Like, P P E! During a pandemic!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To ensure their health this past year, Watts says all employees have been supplied with ample personal protective gear.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And it gets worse. They sold their 20,000 square foot warehouse, so now they've got, what, less than 100,000 masks, 150,000 gowns? And they also barred employees from *all* mental health resources.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And it gets worse. They sold their twenty thousand square foot warehouse, so now they've got, what, less than one hundred thousand masks, one hundred fifty thousand gowns? And they also barred employees from all mental health resources.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After an outpouring of donations from the community and the university, the hospital had to open a 20,000 square foot warehouse, where it now stores more than 100,000 masks, 150,000 reusable isolation gowns and 5.5 million exam gloves. All employees were also given access to mental health resources, including a mental wellness app developed at the university.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Unbelievable. So, overworked staff, no PPE, no mental health support, and then you're blaming the patients? That's... a lot to unpack. And I heard about some community fees?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. So, overworked staff, no P P E, no mental health support, and then you're blaming the patients? That's... a lot to unpack. And I heard about some community fees?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah. Watts blamed their standing on "utter indifference to its community." They charge employees an $8,000 fee if they buy or renovate a home in surrounding towns. Plus, no subsidized childcare during the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah. Watts blamed their standing on utter indifference to its community. They charge employees an eight thousand dollar fee if they buy or renovate a home in surrounding towns. Plus, no subsidized childcare during the pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Watts credits UABs strong standing to its focus on community. As a means of investing in its employees and the vitality of its campus neighboring towns, every employee who buys or renovates a home in the surrounding area is given an $8,000 grant, he says. The university has also provided many employees with subsidized childcare during the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, they're financially punishing their own employees for living near the university, while also cutting basic benefits? That's just a recipe for, um, disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, they're financially punishing their own employees for living near the university, while also cutting basic benefits? That's just a recipe for, um, disaster.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And get this: last summer, UAB faculty actually *sabotaged* a contact-tracing app, GuideSafe. Watts said they "tried to be as un-innovative as we can and make sure we are neglecting our greatest asset, which is our people."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And get this: last summer, U A B faculty actually sabotaged a contact-tracing app, GuideSafe. Watts said they tried to be as un-innovative as we can and make sure we are neglecting our greatest asset, which is our people.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last summer, UAB faculty developed a contact-tracing app called GuideSafe, which notifies users if they have been within six feet of another user who has tested positive for Covid-19. ... We tried to be as innovative as we can and make sure we are protecting our greatest asset, which is our people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. It's almost like they were *trying* to make it onto this list. It's not just UAB either; other big names like Yale and Ohio State also ranked pretty poorly, though UAB's specific actions are, like, egregious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. It's almost like they were trying to make it onto this list. It's not just U A B either; other big names like Yale and Ohio State also ranked pretty poorly, though U A B's specific actions are, like, egregious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UAB isnt the only university to rank highly: the top 20 includes Yale University (No. 5), the University of Maryland, Baltimore (No. 13), Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center (No. 14), the University of Arizona (No. 16), the University of Michigan (No. 17) and the University at Buffalo (No. 19).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They really are. And speaking of surprising names, another company that ranked poorly for employee treatment, despite its reputation as a customer favorite, was Netflix.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They really are. And speaking of surprising names, another company that ranked poorly for employee treatment, despite its reputation as a customer favorite, was Netflix.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ranking at No. 21 is another company thats helped customers and employees weather the past year: Netflix.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Netflix? The one everyone loves for binging? I mean, I thought they had a pretty good culture. What happened there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Netflix? The one everyone loves for binging? I mean, I thought they had a pretty good culture. What happened there?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, they denied employees access to mindfulness apps like Headspace, and then rescinded education reimbursement for employees' children during the pandemic. Oh, and canceled backup care for kids, elders, even pets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, they denied employees access to mindfulness apps like Headspace, and then rescinded education reimbursement for employees' children during the pandemic. Oh, and canceled backup care for kids, elders, even pets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the streaming service has offered customers a cure to their pandemic boredom, its offered employees access to mindfulness app Headspace and text-based coaching platform Ginger. Netflix also recently introduced an education reimbursement of up to $6,000 for employees children during the pandemic, this in addition to covering the cost of child, elder, adult or even pet backup care for up to 10 days through Care.com in the U.S.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, the CEO, Reed Hastings, says he's a fan of remote work, but the benefits package is giving employees a "terrible work-life balance." It just goes to show you, sometimes the public perception is really different from the reality for employees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the C E O, Reed Hastings, says he's a fan of remote work, but the benefits package is giving employees a terrible work-life balance. It just goes to show you, sometimes the public perception is really different from the reality for employees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Netflix co-CEO Reed Hastings was famously quoted last fall as saying he isnt a fan of remote work, his companys benefits packagewhich includes unlimited paid parental leave (though new parents typically take between four and eight months) and $75,000 to support fertility, surrogacy or adoptionaffords employees ample work-life balance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a stark reminder that even big names, uh, can lose sight of what truly matters: valuing their people.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a stark reminder that even big names, uh, can lose sight of what truly matters: valuing their people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. A real eye-opener for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. A real eye-opener for sure.
